clusters.title: Dementia risk for people who quit smoking in middle age ‘same as someone who never smoked’
clusters.neutral_headline: Dementia risk same for quitters as non-smokers

items.title: Dementia risk for people who quit smoking in middle age ‘same as someone who never smoked’
items.standfirst: Research finds kicking the habit halves rate of decline in verbal fluency and slows memory loss by 20%People who stop smoking in middle age can reduce their cognitive decline so dramatically that within 10 years their chances of developing dementia are the same as someone who has never smoked, research has found.Kicking the habit halves the rate of decline in verbal fluency and slows the loss of memory by 20%, according to a study of 9,436 people in England, the US and 10 other European countries. Continue reading...
items.content: Research finds kicking the habit halves rate of decline in verbal fluency and slows memory loss by 20%People who stop smoking in middle age can reduce their cognitive decline so dramatically that within 10 years their chances of developing dementia are the same as someone who has never smoked, research has found.Kicking the habit halves the rate of decline in verbal fluency and slows the loss of memory by 20%, according to a study of 9,436 people in England, the US and 10 other European countries. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Quitting smoking in middle age reduces cognitive decline, research indicates.
It halves the decline in verbal fluency and slows memory loss by 20%.
After ten years, dementia risk equals that of someone who never smoked.
The study involved 9,436 participants from England, the US, and Europe.
Research suggests significant cognitive benefits from quitting smoking later in life.

clusters.title: AI could make it harder to establish blame for medical failings, experts say
clusters.neutral_headline: AI could make it harder to establish blame for medical failings, experts say

items.title: AI could make it harder to establish blame for medical failings, experts say
items.standfirst: Report raises concerns about liability issues and lack of testing as development of AI health tools boomsThe use of artificial intelligence in healthcare could create a legally complex blame game when it comes to establishing liability for medical failings, experts have warned.The development of AI for clinical use has boomed, with researchers creating a host of tools, from algorithms to help interpret scans to systems that can aid with diagnoses. AI is also being developed to help manage hospitals, from optimising bed capacity to tackling supply chains. Continue reading...
items.content: Report raises concerns about liability issues and lack of testing as development of AI health tools boomsThe use of artificial intelligence in healthcare could create a legally complex blame game when it comes to establishing liability for medical failings, experts have warned.The development of AI for clinical use has boomed, with researchers creating a host of tools, from algorithms to help interpret scans to systems that can aid with diagnoses. AI is also being developed to help manage hospitals, from optimising bed capacity to tackling supply chains. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The use of AI in healthcare may complicate liability for medical errors.
Experts raise concerns about testing and accountability in AI health tools.
AI is being developed for tasks like interpreting scans and aiding diagnoses.
AI is also being used to manage hospitals, optimizing bed capacity.
The rapid growth of AI in healthcare raises legal and ethical questions.

clusters.title: Sharp global rise in antibiotic-resistant infections in hospitals, WHO finds
clusters.neutral_headline: Sharp global rise in antibiotic-resistant infections in hospitals, WHO finds

items.title: Sharp global rise in antibiotic-resistant infections in hospitals, WHO finds
items.standfirst: Experts describe findings as deeply concerning and predict 70% increase in related deaths by 2050Hospitals across the world have recorded an alarming rise in common infections that are resistant to antibiotics, with doctors saying the number of deaths driven by drug resistance will increase sharply in the years ahead.One in six laboratory-confirmed bacterial infections were resistant to antibiotic treatments in 2023, with more than 40% of antibiotics losing potency against common blood, gut, urinary tract and sexually-transmitted infections between 2018 and 2023, records show. Continue reading...
items.content: Experts describe findings as deeply concerning and predict 70% increase in related deaths by 2050Hospitals across the world have recorded an alarming rise in common infections that are resistant to antibiotics, with doctors saying the number of deaths driven by drug resistance will increase sharply in the years ahead.One in six laboratory-confirmed bacterial infections were resistant to antibiotic treatments in 2023, with more than 40% of antibiotics losing potency against common blood, gut, urinary tract and sexually-transmitted infections between 2018 and 2023, records show. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Hospitals worldwide are seeing a rise in antibiotic-resistant infections.
Experts are concerned, predicting a 70% increase in related deaths by 2050.
One in six infections in 2023 were resistant to antibiotics.
Over 40% of antibiotics lost potency against common infections between 2018-2023.
The WHO findings highlight a critical public health challenge.

clusters.title: Is it true that … cutting out carbs helps you lose weight?
clusters.neutral_headline: Cutting out carbs helps you lose weight?

items.title: Is it true that … cutting out carbs helps you lose weight?
items.standfirst: Weight loss is about consuming fewer calories than you burn, and reducing your intake of refined carbohydrates can play a part in thatThis is a bit of a grey area, says Bethan Crouse, a performance nutritionist at Loughborough University. She wouldn’t advise the athletes she works with to completely cut out carbohydrates – foods such as bread, grains, potatoes and sweets. “However,” she says, “reducing carbohydrate intake can be beneficial for weight loss, if we can moderate total energy intake.”Weight loss comes down to energy balance: consuming fewer calories than we burn. There are many ways to achieve this: exercising more, eating less, or choosing foods that are lower in calories. Cutting back on some carbohydrates can be one way to create this deficit, she says. Not because carbs are uniquely “fattening”, but because other macronutrients such as fibre, protein and fat tend to be more filling. “If we spend more of our calorie budget on these foods, we feel fuller for longer,” Crouse says. Continue reading...
items.content: Weight loss is about consuming fewer calories than you burn, and reducing your intake of refined carbohydrates can play a part in thatThis is a bit of a grey area, says Bethan Crouse, a performance nutritionist at Loughborough University. She wouldn’t advise the athletes she works with to completely cut out carbohydrates – foods such as bread, grains, potatoes and sweets. “However,” she says, “reducing carbohydrate intake can be beneficial for weight loss, if we can moderate total energy intake.”Weight loss comes down to energy balance: consuming fewer calories than we burn. There are many ways to achieve this: exercising more, eating less, or choosing foods that are lower in calories. Cutting back on some carbohydrates can be one way to create this deficit, she says. Not because carbs are uniquely “fattening”, but because other macronutrients such as fibre, protein and fat tend to be more filling. “If we spend more of our calorie budget on these foods, we feel fuller for longer,” Crouse says. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Weight loss depends on consuming fewer calories than burned, experts say.
Reducing refined carbohydrates can contribute to weight loss.
Cutting carbs can be beneficial if it moderates total energy intake.
Carbs are not uniquely fattening, but other foods are more filling.
Focusing on protein, fiber, and fat can help with feeling full.

clusters.title: Woman, 53, becomes UK’s longest survivor of heart and lung transplant
clusters.neutral_headline: Woman, 53, becomes UK’s longest survivor of heart and lung transplant

items.title: Woman, 53, becomes UK’s longest survivor of heart and lung transplant
items.standfirst: Katie Mitchell had procedure at 15 after being diagnosed with Eisenmenger syndrome, a rare congenital diseaseAt the age of 15, Katie Mitchell was told by medics that she was nearing the end of her life after suffering irreversible lung damage and heart failure from a rare congenital disease.But she defied the odds thanks to a heart and lung transplant, and at the age of 53 she has become the UK’s longest-surviving recipient of such a procedure. Continue reading...
items.content: Katie Mitchell had procedure at 15 after being diagnosed with Eisenmenger syndrome, a rare congenital diseaseAt the age of 15, Katie Mitchell was told by medics that she was nearing the end of her life after suffering irreversible lung damage and heart failure from a rare congenital disease.But she defied the odds thanks to a heart and lung transplant, and at the age of 53 she has become the UK’s longest-surviving recipient of such a procedure. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Katie Mitchell, 53, is the longest survivor of a heart and lung transplant in the UK.
She had the procedure at 15 due to Eisenmenger syndrome.
The rare congenital disease caused irreversible lung damage and heart failure.
Mitchell defied medical expectations and has lived for many years.
Her story highlights the success of transplant medicine.

clusters.title: High youth death rates are an ‘emerging crisis’, global health study warns
clusters.neutral_headline: High youth death rates are an ‘emerging crisis’, global health study warns

items.title: High youth death rates are an ‘emerging crisis’, global health study warns
items.standfirst: Alcohol, suicide and injuries driving rises among teenagers and young adults despite overall rates falling, authors say The world faces “an emerging crisis” of higher death rates among teenagers and young adults, according to a major study on the causes of death and disability worldwide.The reasons vary from drug and alcohol use, and suicide in North America, to infectious diseases and injuries in sub-Saharan Africa, the researchers said, but warned that their data should serve as “a wake-up call”.In the UK and Ireland, Samaritans can be contacted on freephone 116 123, or email jo@samaritans.org or jo@samaritans.ie. In the US, you can call or text the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline on 988, chat on 988lifeline.org, or text HOME to 741741 to connect with a crisis counsellor. In Australia, the crisis support service Lifeline is 13 11 14. Other international helplines can be found at befrienders.org Continue reading...
items.content: Alcohol, suicide and injuries driving rises among teenagers and young adults despite overall rates falling, authors say The world faces “an emerging crisis” of higher death rates among teenagers and young adults, according to a major study on the causes of death and disability worldwide.The reasons vary from drug and alcohol use, and suicide in North America, to infectious diseases and injuries in sub-Saharan Africa, the researchers said, but warned that their data should serve as “a wake-up call”.In the UK and Ireland, Samaritans can be contacted on freephone 116 123, or email jo@samaritans.org or jo@samaritans.ie. In the US, you can call or text the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline on 988, chat on 988lifeline.org, or text HOME to 741741 to connect with a crisis counsellor. In Australia, the crisis support service Lifeline is 13 11 14. Other international helplines can be found at befrienders.org Continue reading...

ai_summary: A global study warns of rising death rates among teenagers and young adults.
Alcohol, suicide, and injuries are driving increases in some regions.
The study highlights the need for action to address the crisis.
The article provides resources for those struggling with mental health.
The research serves as a wake-up call for global health initiatives.
